image.altText: Six men in camo uniform stand in formation. At the front, Caesar speaks to the camera

items.synopsis: Wagner's mutiny may be over, but from secret locations inside Russia and Ukraine, guerilla groups are dodging Moscow's crackdown on dissidents to sabotage Putin's plans and help Ukraine win the war.

title.children: Putin may have dealt with the Wagner threat, but another group of militants are threatening to bring him down

image.altText: men walking

items.synopsis: On Chinese social media, users referred to the Wagner chief by using the names of historical Chinese rebels to share their views on China's heavily censored internet.

title.children: Beijing downplays Wagner mutiny as experts say China might re-evaluate partnership with Russia

image.altText: Busy city street with police cars blocking off crime scene in Sydney's Bondi Junction

items.synopsis: Convicted drug kingpin Alen Moradian is believed to have been shot in an underground car park. Two cars, one of which was burnt out, have been found in nearby areas.

title.children: Police say underworld figure shot dead in car in Sydney's east was 'major player with a big target'

image.altText: An old newspaper article on the death of Vincenzo D'Agostino, the leader of The Black Hand.

items.synopsis: For years, Vincenzo D'Agostino terrorised and extorted Italian migrants across Far North Queensland as leader of the mafia group the Black Hand. His rule was a defining period for the regional Italian community, but one fact remains unsolved — who turned the tables, and murdered him?

title.children: The Black Hand reigned with fear for almost 10 years in north Queensland. This is how its leader was brought undone

items.synopsis: The long-awaited preliminary flight paths for Western Sydney Airport are now public and residents can use an online tool to determine the noise impacts over their properties.

title.children: Flight paths revealed for new multi-billion-dollar Sydney airport

image.altText: The PwC logo is shown on an office building.

items.synopsis: In a sublime combination of breathtaking arrogance and dazzling ineptitude, the Australian arm of global accounting giant PwC has managed to turn a possible crime into a national crisis and then allowed it to evolve into a catastrophe, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Can a $1 deal save PwC or will it follow Arthur Andersen into oblivion?

image.altText: three men stand in front of cricket nets, all holding cricket bats

items.synopsis: They might not have the pace of the Australian Ashes squad, but this team of cricketers is just as committed to nailing a few wins against the Poms.

title.children: Age no barrier for Australian cricket squad chasing Grey Ashes glory

image.altText: A composite image with 'ice, ice baby' written on a car bonnet and frost on another car window

items.synopsis: Perth records coldest morning in seven years at 0.7 Celsius, while even lower temperatures are recorded in other parts of WA, including -2.6C in the Wheatbelt town of Wandering.

title.children: Freezing conditions deliver Perth its coldest morning since 2016 along with sub-zero temperatures

image.altText: A three kilometre sea wall between East Point and Nightcliff, part of the Arafura Harbour proposal

items.synopsis: Police say the DNA of a 49-year-old man matches one of two DNA profiles obtained during the investigation of a sexual assault at Darwin's East Point 30 years ago.

title.children: Two men charged over 1993 Darwin sexual assault using historical DNA samples

image.altText: An old grainy photo of a man in a top hat crouched before two toddlers

items.synopsis: For 40 years, a cardboard box sat unopened under a house. Inside, were  not only precious memories of a family but a unique glimpse into life in the 1930s and 1940s.

title.children: Paul found a box with '2km worth of film' under his parents' house. Now it is a national treasure

image.altText: An office worker talks on his phone as he looks the stock board at the Australian Securities Exchange

items.synopsis: Australia's financial regulator APRA forces Medibank to hold an extra $250 million in capital after last year's massive data breach, while the local share market has recovers slightly from its three-month low.

title.children: Medibank forced to hold extra $250m in capital after data breach, ASX opens higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has risen slightly in morning trade, with the ASX 200 up 0.4% to 7,108 points. Several of today's best performing stocks are in the property sector, including Scentre Group (+3.6%), Mirvac (+2.7%) and GPT Group (+2.7%). Medibank Private dropped 4.2% after the financial regulator APRA imposed a requirement for the health insurer to set aside an extra $250 million in capital, following last year's significant data breach. Shares of Megaport (-2.5%), Paladin Energy (-2.2%) and Lovisa Holdings (-2%) are also experiencing heavy losses.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Real estate stocks drive ASX higher

children.content: The Australian share market has risen slightly in morning trade, with the ASX 200 up 0.4% to 7,108 points.
Several of today's best performing stocks are in the property sector, including Scentre Group (+3.6%), Mirvac (+2.7%) and GPT Group (+2.7%).

Medibank Private dropped 4.2% after the financial regulator APRA imposed a requirement for the health insurer to set aside an extra $250 million in capital, following last year's significant data breach.
Shares of Megaport (-2.5%), Paladin Energy (-2.2%) and Lovisa Holdings (-2%) are also experiencing heavy losses.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Medibank Private says it will provide "full support and work collaboratively" with the financial regulator APRA on a remediation program, following last year's massive data breach. Earlier today, APRA said it would impose a requirement on Medibank to set aside an extra $250 million in capital from July 1, in reponse to last year's hack which resulted in 9.7 million customer records being leaked to the dark web. The health insurer said it has "sufficient existing capital" to meet this additional burden. "After application of this requirement Medibank will remain well capitalised with unallocated capital remaining at 30 June 2022 levels, which was $148 million," the company wrote in a statement. "As a result of this Medibank will not currently reduce its target health insurance required capital ratio". At least three separate class action lawsuits have been filed in Australian courts on behalf of affected customers against the company over the network intrusion. Although Medibank has already addressed the specific control weaknesses that permitted unauthorised access to its systems, it still has more work to do across a number of areas to boost its security environment and data management, APRA said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Medibank says it will cooperate with APRA's remediation program

children.content: Medibank Private says it will provide "full support and work collaboratively" with the financial regulator APRA on a remediation program, following last year's massive data breach.

Earlier today, APRA said it would impose a requirement on Medibank to set aside an extra $250 million in capital from July 1, in reponse to last year's hack which resulted in 9.7 million customer records being leaked to the dark web.
The health insurer said it has "sufficient existing capital" to meet this additional burden.
"After application of this requirement Medibank will remain well capitalised with unallocated capital remaining at 30 June 2022 levels, which was $148 million," the company wrote in a statement.
"As a result of this Medibank will not currently reduce its target health insurance required capital ratio".
At least three separate class action lawsuits have been filed in Australian courts on behalf of affected customers against the company over the network intrusion.

Although Medibank has already addressed the specific control weaknesses that permitted unauthorised access to its systems, it still has more work to do across a number of areas to boost its security environment and data management, APRA said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Prudential and Regulation Authority ( APRA ) will force Medibank Private to hold an extra $250 million in capital, as punishment for last year's data breach — which resulted in the records of 9.7 million customers being stolen and released on the dark web. Essentially, that's money or assets that Medibank needs to set aside, which can't be used for other purposes. The financial regulator said this measure will take effect from July 1, and will remain in place "until an agreed remediation program of work is completed by Medibank to APRA's satisfaction". APRA also said it will conduct a "targeted technology review" of the health insurer, focusing on its governance and risk culture. “In taking this action, APRA seeks to ensure that Medibank expedites its remediation program,” said APRA member Suzanne Smith. "APRA expects Medibank to ensure there is appropriate accountability and consequence management, including impacts to executive remuneration where appropriate. Ms Smith added that her organisation continues to see "poor cyber security practices and inadequate oversight from boards and management".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: APRA penalises Medibank for last year's hacking scandal

children.content: The Australian Prudential and Regulation Authority (
APRA
) will force
Medibank Private
to hold an extra
$250 million
in capital, as punishment for last year's data breach — which resulted in the records of
9.7 million customers
being stolen and released on the dark web.
Essentially, that's money or assets that Medibank needs to set aside, which can't be used for other purposes.
The financial regulator said this measure will take effect from July 1, and will remain in place "until an agreed remediation program of work is completed by Medibank to APRA's satisfaction".
APRA also said it will conduct a "targeted technology review" of the health insurer, focusing on its governance and risk culture.
“In taking this action, APRA seeks to ensure that Medibank expedites its remediation program,” said APRA member Suzanne Smith.
"APRA expects Medibank to ensure there is appropriate accountability and consequence management, including impacts to executive remuneration where appropriate.
Ms Smith added that her organisation continues to see "poor cyber security practices and inadequate oversight from boards and management".

image.altText: A woman looks out at a path

items.synopsis: As police increase patrols in areas where assaults have occurred, some women are opting to carry personal alarms or exercise without headphones.

title.children: Women avoid one of Alice Springs' most popular walking trails in wake of indecent assaults

image.altText: A man in a high-vis shirt standing inside a warehouse and smiling.

items.synopsis: In some communities where the federal government's changes to the remote work-for-the-dole program are being trialled, residents like Chris Farrell are reporting success.

title.children: 'Keep it going': Indigenous communities appeal for better work-for-the-dole conditions to continue

image.altText: Slightly smiling older woman, short grey hair, glasses, a white and black blouse with flutter sleeves, black-rimmed glasses.

items.synopsis: An outage that has been going on for two weeks and has technicians stumped is leaving Tottenham residents unable to access basic communication services.

title.children: Mary drives hours just to use the phone. Telstra is cut off in her town, but no-one knows why

image.altText: A man sits at a desk with building plans standing behind him

items.synopsis: In the 2022-23 financial year, 132 construction businesses in Western Australia went into administration — and nationally, about 2,000 building companies shut their doors.

title.children: Two years ago this builder warned government stimulus could overcook the sector. It looks like he was right

image.altText: Blue and white police tape in front of a wire fence with men standing near railways lines in the background

items.synopsis: A man who died after being hit by a train in Tasmania's north-west early on Monday morning was homeless, police say.

title.children: Homeless man dies after being hit by a train, police say

image.altText: Joe Biden in sunglasses speaking while Anthony Albanese looks on

items.synopsis: Senior US officials say they are in talks with a "variety" of other countries about potentially involving them in the second phase of the AUKUS agreement, with artificial intelligence and quantum technologies on the table.

title.children: AUKUS could expand in second phase to include other countries, US officials say

image.altText: A submersible under sea with air bubbles coming out from the top.

items.synopsis: An international investigation into the cause of the undersea implosion of a tourist submersible that killed all five people on board is underway. So, what happens next?

title.children: What happens next with the wreckage of OceanGate's submersible Titan?

image.altText: a typical looking hamburger with meat type filling and lettuce

items.synopsis: The national food standards body is assessing an application to sell a range of luxury lab meat products while another company with a cultured lamb burger is watching to see how things shake out.

title.children: Plant-based meat is already out there — now real meat grown in a lab could soon be on the grocery list

image.altText: An older woman with blonde hair stands with arm around waist of taller man in hoodie in gym

items.synopsis: When Toni Wolfe, 71, benched 80kg on Sunday she broke an all-time powerlifting world record. Now she has her sights set on becoming world champion.

title.children: 'Complete surprise': Great grandmother breaks powerlifting world record

image.altText: Two ornate chairs near a small round table in an ornate room at the Versailles Palace in France

items.synopsis: The Palace of Versailles reopens the private rooms of France's last queen, after five years of intricate restoration.

title.children: Marie Antoinette's Versailles apartment reopens to the public after five years of restoration

image.altText: Wagner mercenary fighters on top of a tank, with a Wagner flag.

items.synopsis: A former Russian diplomat who defected from his post at the United Nations in 2022 says Vladimir Putin's inner circle is shrinking and most people inside the Kremlin do not support the war against Ukraine.

title.children: 'Majority of people in the Kremlin unhappy about this war', Russia defector reveals

image.altText: A woman wearing a hair net and apron stands on a factory production line with co-workers assembling speakers

items.synopsis: Australia is relying on its largest trading partner to bounce back, but China's youth unemployment figures and low consumer confidence are slowing down much-needed growth, suggesting a full recovery will take some time.

title.children: China's post-COVID economic recovery appears to be sputtering. Here's why

image.altText: Black and white photo of Nel Law smiling slightly with closed mouth, against plain background, wearing woolen turtleneck jumper.

items.synopsis: The rules prevented women from going to Antarctica in the 1960s, but Nel Law defied them. Now author Rachael Mead wants more people to learn about Nel's legacy.

title.children: In the 60s, Nel Law was a stowaway on a ship to Antarctica. What she saw there blew her mind

image.altText: A police car and tape

items.synopsis: Police received a report that a number of people were in the vicinity of the injured teenager, and they appeared to be armed with a knife.

title.children: Teenage boy, 14, dies after being found injured on road in Melbourne's north-west

image.altText: An Australian tennis player brandishes his racquet, ready to hit a forehand as the ball comes toward him at Wimbledon.

items.synopsis: Thanasi Kokkinakis is knocked out in the first round of Wimbledon qualifying but three other Aussies make it to the second round.

title.children: Kokkinakis knocked out in Wimbledon qualifying, Tomljanovic out with injury

image.altText: Nvidia logo displayed on a mobile phone screen with a circuit board in the background.

items.synopsis: The company behind much of the technology fuelling artificial intelligence has seen its shares surge almost 200 per cent this year as part of a wider AI boom, but are those sky-high valuations justified?

title.children: This company's AI potential just 'blew everything out of the park', but can it live up to its surging share value?

image.altText: Gwenda Darling, a woman with pink hair, stands in a garden wearing a black scarf and striped jumper.

items.synopsis: Gwenda struggled with her dementia diagnosis at first, but now she's looking forward to the future and "living her best life".

title.children: Gwenda was told she had five years to live after a dementia diagnosis. That was 11 years ago

image.altText: A close up photo of what appears to be orange citrus fruit with blue-grey mould on it

items.synopsis: Usually, mould spores are invisible — but give them a niche to exploit and you'll get all kinds of colours on the things in your home, writes Michael Taylor.

title.children: Black, blue, yellow or pink: What do the different colours of mould in my house mean?

image.altText: A group of smiling Australian cricketers raise their hands for a high five to congratulate a bowler after she takes a wicket.

items.synopsis: The win at Trent Bridge which puts Australia halfway to retaining the Women's Ashes, comes despite two of its stars, spinner Ashleigh Gardner and skipper Alyssa Healy, playing all five days with finger injuries.

title.children: Gardner, Healy overcome fickle fingers to spur Australia to Women's Ashes Test win
